awd_titl_txt: Dynamic Multivariate Normative Comparison and Risk Screening for Alzheimer's Disease Progression
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on the development of statistical methods for analyzing data from the Alzheimer Disease (AD) Research Center (ADRC).  The first objective is to develop robust procedures to classify cognitive impairment over repeated visits. This has important clinical implications, as current diagnostic methods tend to falsely flag healthy subjects as impaired.  The second project focuses on systematic evaluation of high-dimensional risk factors to select promising features that can separate those subjects who will develop AD, from those who might die, and those who will be alive and disease free by a certain time point.  The completion of this project will lead to the identification of important risk factors that are predictive of both AD and survival.  These newly identified biological, clinical, and genetic markers will guide future studies developing targeted intervention for AD.  The proposed methods are relevant for disease diagnosis and risk screening but may also be applied to other areas such as economics, finance and engineering.  The project will integrate research and education through the mentoring of graduate students. 

The first project concerns longitudinal measures of multiple domain scores of cognitive functioning modeled using multivariate mixed-effect models.  A longitudinal multivariate normative comparison (MNC) statistic is then computed to measure the distance between a subject's domain scores and the estimated norm of healthy controls. Different thresholding methods are proposed for the longitudinal MNC based on the Chi-square approximation and permutation to identify cognitive impairment from retrospective data.  Two familywise-error-rate controlling procedures are developed to dynamically screen for cognitive impairment at each ongoing visit, by comparing the p-values from the longitudinal MNC with adaptive significance levels. In the second project, a recently developed diagnostic measure of the volume under the ROC surface (VUS) is adopted as a model-free screening metric for ordinal competing endpoints. The VUS can be readily estimated as a concordance probability by some weighted U-statistics. The proposed screening procedure based on the U-type estimator of the VUS provides systematic and dynamic evaluation of markers' discriminatory capacity without any model assumptions. As the first screening method developed specifically for ordinal disease progression, the successful completion of the second project will contribute to the broader field of high-dimensional risk screening.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this application, we introduced a series of statistical methods to address real-world challenges in analyzing data from the Alzheimer Disease (AD) Research Center (ADRC) and the Multicenter AIDS Cohort Study (MACS). Our first objective was to develop both static and dynamic classification procedures to assess cognitive impairment across multiple visits while controlling the false discovery rate. This is clinically significant, as current quantitative diagnostic methods often mistakenly classify healthy individuals as impaired.

The second goal was to systematically evaluate high-dimensional risk factors to identify features that can distinguish between individuals likely to develop AD, those at risk of death, and those who will remain alive and disease-free by a given time point. The successful completion of this project provides researchers with tools to identify factors predictive of both AD progression and survival.

Specifically, our first project focused on longitudinal assessments of multiple cognitive domain scores, using multivariate mixed-effect models. We calculated a Longitudinal Multivariate Normative Comparison (LMNC) statistic to measure the deviation of a subject's scores from the estimated norms of healthy controls. To identify cognitive impairment from retrospective data, we proposed thresholding methods for the LMNC, using Chi-square approximation and permutation techniques. This work, which was published in Statistics in Medicine (2021), was designed for  research settings where data had already been collected, enabling a single retrospective classification of impairment for each patient.

In practice, participants often return to the same clinician or institution for multiple visits. For example, participants visiting an ADRC with memory concerns are generally followed annually, and their cognitive functioning assessed repeatedly over time. To detect cognitive impairment at each ongoing visit, we introduced a visit-specific classification method called Dynamic Arrayed Comparisons (DAC) and developed two procedures that control the familywise error rate by comparing p-values from the incremental LMNC to adaptive significance levels. The proposed DAC method, published in Statistics in Medicine (2023), offers greater utility by enabling visit-by-visit diagnoses. To facilitate the implementation of our methods, we have made our code available on GitHub at https://github.com/tlwangzi123/Dynamic-Arrayed-Comparison and developed an R Shiny app (https://lingyun-hiny.shinyapps.io/DACShinnyApp/) that visualizes individual scores over time and illustrates dynamic classification using simulated domain scores, as the MACS neuropsychological data are not publicly available. The DAC method, along with the LMNC approach, has broad applicability for longitudinal data and dynamic classification tasks, and the app can be easily adapted for other contexts.

Our second project used a recently developed diagnostic measure, the volume under the ROC surface (VUS), as a model-free screening metric for ordinal competing endpoints. The VUS can be estimated as a concordance probability using weighted U-statistics. Our proposed screening procedure, based on the U-type estimator of the VUS, provides a systematic and dynamic way to evaluate markers' discriminatory power without relying on model assumptions. This work was published in Lifetime Data Analysis (2023). As the first screening method designed specifically for ordinal disease progression, this project contributes to the broader field of high-dimensional risk screening. Additionally, new biological, clinical, and genetic markers discovered through this research will guide future studies aiming to develop targeted interventions for AD. The proposed methods have broader applications beyond medicine, extending to fields such as economics, finance, and engineering. Furthermore, graduate students were actively involved in both projects, seamlessly integrating the research with educational goals.
